_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The management of Golden State Vintners Winery Fresno is committed to maintaining a safe work environment. Safety and Environmental Managers have been assigned to ensure safe practices are followed in the specification and operation of systems involving hazardous chemicals. The site has developed an Emergency Response Plan and trained its personnel to ensure prompt evacuations during an ammonia emergency. The Plan has specific written evacuation and reporting procedures in place to protect Fresno Winery employees, the public, and the environment in the event of an ammonia release.

	Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

The Fresno Winery facility covered by this RMP is located at 7409 W. Central Avenue in Fresno, California. The facility produces grape juice that is fermented into wine. The facility uses sulfur dioxide for bacterial control and anhydrous ammonia for refrigeration. 
A stationary anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system is used for chilling wine. The Ammonia System at the facility has fifteen chillers and contains a total of less than 150,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia. Refrigeration equipment and piping are located outdoors. Based on this quantity of anhydrous ammonia, the facility is subject to the Program 3 RMP requirements.
The facility also uses a sulfur dioxide system located in the North East part of the winery. Sulfur dioxide is stored in two 1-ton cylinders and is used to supply and fill smaller hand-held sulfur dioxide cylinders, having capacities of 25 and 100 pounds. The sulfur dioxide is injected from the smaller cylinders into the wine to control the bacteria. This system holds a maximum of 4,250 pounds of sulfur dioxide, and is currently exempt from RMP requirements.

Note: The amount of sulfur dioxide onsite (4,250 pounds) is below the threshold amount required by the federal RMP regulation. The Sanger facility has not received formal notification fr

om the Administering Agency (AA) that pursuant to Section 25534 of HSC an RMP is required to satisfy CalARP Program requirements as they pertain to sulfur dioxide, this plan only addresses federal RMP requirements as they pertain to ammonia.


	Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Prevention of accidental ammonia and sulfur dioxide releases at The Wine Group¿s Golden State Vintners Winery Fresno Facility is accomplished through sound industry practice in the original design and construction of the ammonia refrigeration and sulfur dioxide systems (i.e., double-block scenario relief valves, ASME cylinders), the specification and review of system modifications, and the day-to-day operation and maintenance of the systems, including the following: 

¿Compliance with industry standards and codes in effect at initial construction and modification
¿Thorough Process Hazard Analyses (PHA) at least every 5 years using accurate process safety information
¿Operating Procedures reviewed by PHA
¿Appropriate initial and refresher training of system operations and maintenance personnel
¿Preventive and corrective maintenance 
¿Established auditing, inspection, and pre-start-up review protocols
¿Use of qualified contractors for work on the system


	Five Year Accident History

Between June 1999 and the present, there has been 1 ammonia release and no sulfur dioxide releases. The ammonia release did not result in any onsite or off-site injuries, deaths, or property damage, or in any off-site environmental damage, or evacuations. The single ammonia release did require sheltering in place of 4 individuals. The incident was reported to the proper authorities and they responded. A full investigation was completed after the incident, and it was determined that the cause of the incident was due to human error, resulting in over pressuring the system. Subsequent to the incident review, the operating procedures were amended and the applicable personnel

trained to the revised and updated procedures that the facility developed, adopted, and implemented.

	Emergency Response Program

The Fresno Winery has developed an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) containing procedures to adequately and rapidly respond to an ammonia release emergency, as well as other site emergencies. The ERP, kept at the Plant Office, describes outside agency notification procedures in the event of an ammonia release. It details evacuation procedures and response procedures for the mitigation of minor ammonia releases. The Fresno County Fire Department will generally respond to any non-minor leaks or leaks that cannot be repaired. Employees are trained to this ERP and, in the event of a non-minor leak, will evacuate and take initial life safety precautions, as described in the ERP.

	Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Based on studies conducted during preparation of this RMP, the Fresno Winery facility plans to implement many changes in their procedures, practices, policies, including several minor equipment adjustments to ensure continued safe operations. These items were discovered during a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) that was conducted at the facility December 2, 2004. All of the changes and adjustments have been enumerated in the facility¿s PHA document, dated December 2004.

	RMP Review and Update

This RMP will be reviewed at least once every five years and updated as appropriate.  This RMP will be updated if any of the following situations apply:

¿No more than 3 years after a newly regulated substance is first listed by USEPA or Office of Emergency Services (OES)
¿No later than the date on which a regulated substance is first present in an already covered process above a threshold quantity
¿No later than the date on which a new regulated substance is first present above a threshold quantity in a new process
¿Within 6 months of a change that requires a revised PHA or hazard review
¿Within 6 months of a change that requires a revised off-si
